ch1.txt.summary:
“Two such charming children. The prince bowed to signify his respect and gratitude. The prince was silent and looked indifferent. None. He had just entered, wearing an
embroidered court uniform, knee breeches, and shoes, and had stars on
his breast and a serene expression on his flat face.

ch2.txt.summary:
Here the conversation seemed interesting and he stood waiting for an
opportunity to express his own views, as young people are fond of doing. With his head bent, and his big feet
spread apart, he began explaining his reasons for thinking the abbé’s
plan chimerical. One of the next arrivals was a stout, heavily built young man with
close-cropped hair, spectacles, the light-colored breeches fashionable
at that time, a very high ruffle, and a brown dress coat. The young Princess Bolkónskaya had brought some work in a
gold-embroidered velvet bag. And each visitor,
though politeness prevented his showing impatience, left the old woman
with a sense of relief at having performed a vexatious duty and did not
return to her the whole evening.

ch3.txt.summary:
His eyes, nose, and
mouth all seemed puckered into a vacant, wearied grimace, and his arms
and legs always fell into unnatural positions. The little princess had also left the tea table and followed Hélène. The princess rested her bare round arm on a little table and considered
a reply unnecessary. The princess smiled. The vicomte wished to begin his story and gave a subtle smile.

ch4.txt.summary:
But as soon as the prince had gone her face
resumed its former cold, artificial expression. Apparently she had forgotten her age and by force of habit employed
all the old feminine arts. This last consideration moved him. Everything about
him, from his weary, bored expression to his quiet, measured step,
offered a most striking contrast to his quiet, little wife. He was a very handsome young
man, of medium height, with firm, clearcut features.

ch5.txt.summary: Suddenly there was a great wind. Revolution and regicide a grand thing?... The vicomte merely shrugged his shoulders. The princess listened, smiling. Adorable!

ch6.txt.summary:
I don’t know. Pierre turned his whole body, making the sofa creak. The postilion started, the carriage wheels rattled. Two footmen, the princess’ and his own, stood holding a shawl and
a cloak, waiting for the conversation to finish. “Write to her and let me know how her father looks at the matter.

ch7.txt.summary:
Her beautiful eyes
glanced askance at her husband’s face, and her own assumed the timid,
deprecating expression of a dog when it rapidly but feebly wags its
drooping tail. Suddenly the angry, squirrel-like expression of the princess’ pretty
face changed into a winning and piteous look of fear. The princess said nothing, but suddenly her short downy lip quivered. The princess started. The rustle of a woman’s dress was heard in the next room.

ch8.txt.summary:
Every muscle of his
thin face was now quivering with nervous excitement; his eyes, in which
the fire of life had seemed extinguished, now flashed with brilliant
light. Pierre took off his spectacles, which made his face seem different and
the good-natured expression still more apparent, and gazed at his friend
in amazement. They entered the elegant, newly decorated, and luxurious dining room. Neither cared to begin talking. The friends were silent.

ch9.txt.summary:
Fine fellow!... Anatole stood erect with staring
eyes. Pierre stood smiling but silent. Listen! Pierre took an open cab intending
to drive straight home.

ch10.txt.summary:
A tall, stout, and proud-looking woman, with a round-faced smiling
daughter, entered the drawing room, their dresses rustling. That’s right! These words he repeated to everyone without exception or variation, and
with the same expression on his full, cheerful, clean-shaven face, the
same firm pressure of the hand and the same quick, repeated bows. The young
people were in one of the inner rooms, not considering it necessary to
take part in receiving the visitors. A languor of motion and speech, resulting from weakness, gave her a
distinguished air which inspired respect.
